posts.cooked:
NBC News

Abortion clinics are ditching emails, texts in favor of encrypted apps as...

Some clinic employees say they are embracing encrypted messaging apps and Zoom meetings to leave less of an electronic paper trail.

The Daily Beast

Post-Roe Panic: Women Urge Each Other to Delete Period Tracking Apps

Two of the most popular apps have vowed to keep users‚Äô data safe.

Now that women and abortion clinics are again under political persecution in the US, a Signal for Business client would probably help those in need to keep communications between clinics and clients safe. Think like iMessage or WhatsApp do it for business.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
I do not think Signal is viable for businesses, especially health care, due to data retention laws. Apple and Facebook retain user data and hold the encryption keys to that data which is why they have versions of their apps for business.

I personally think the best use of Signal would be for coordinating getting people that need help and live in backwards states out of those backward states.

One should question why that data should be stored anywhere else than the users device. Storage of health data in online databases is begging for abuse (as the corona pandemic has taugt us - again).

posts.cooked: Storage of health data in the U.S. is a difficult problem. Even with HIPAA healthcare privacy laws in the U.S. there are still too many loopholes. And now with the reversal of Roe there will undoubtedly be a new surveillance market (especially in Texas and a few other states where you will be paid to persecute people) specifically for targeting people looking for help if an actual digital privacy law isn‚Äôt passed.

10^6 I mean that‚Äôs like a million!!! No human could possibly crack that in a life time!!!

posts.name: Simon Mackay
posts.cooked:
I support the idea of a ‚ÄúSignal For Business‚Äù for all business types. This could be facilitated with a Desktop client which runs on Windows / MacOS / Linux / ChromeOS but works independently of a smartphone running the Signal mobile app. Here, each user would be addressed with an address similar to an email address so as to allow ‚Äúuser/office/organisation‚Äù addressing.

There would still be the support for end-to-end encryption and ‚Äúon-premises‚Äù data retention by the business incase they need this for customer service. This could even be limited to having the data retained only on the same workstation as the software. But it could support automatic data purging after a period defined by the business so as to assure user privacy.

Such an app or setup could be offered as a premium extra-cost service for most ‚Äúfor-profit‚Äù businesses that aren‚Äôt for the community, with this money going towards keeping the Signal Foundation alive.

posts.name: Steven
posts.cooked:
Note that Matrix just released Chatterbox which seems to be a better solution to online chatting with a business.

But I do think Signal could still be used. My doctor had me download this random app just to video chat with her and she said it was because it was encrypted. I‚Äôm sure they are paying a lot for the service too. Signal would have been an easy drop in replacement here.
aren‚Äôt patient - doctor conversations, already protected by HIPAA laws ?

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Roe v Wade is just the first domino to fall that‚Äôs going to lead to the obliteration of privacy specifically around personal health and health care.

Give it time and HIPAA will eventually either not exist or there‚Äôll be an exception for abortion, being gay, being trans, use of contraception, and myriad other health-related things. One of the SCOTUS judges that voted to kill Roe already said in so many words ‚ÄúWe shouldn‚Äôt stop at Roe‚Äù.

So whether for business or not, Signal just became the most important tool for Americans that are not rich, white, straight, male, and Christian. Forty years ago ‚ÄúThe Handmaid‚Äôs Tale‚Äù was a book. For the last five years it‚Äôs been a TV show. Now watch it become reality, or scarily close to it.

Avitus:

whether for business or not, Signal just became the most important tool for Americans

And my experience has been that many smartphone owners still don‚Äôt (care to) have a good grasp on why they need it, which is concerning.

Avitus:

and Christian

This is an interesting point, because I think the real problem is whether or not one fits the politically sanctioned idea of Christian, irrespective of the life and teachings of Christ (which anyone could read and use to refute the popular ideology). The concerning part there should be that this is so frighteningly applicable across any number of topics beyond religion. Being an X won‚Äôt keep you safe if you‚Äôre not in line with the idea of X held by the people in power.

That should be moving a lot of people from all walks of life towards encryption, right?

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
anon61006462:

patient - doctor conversations, already protected by HIPAA laws ?

Only in the US. In other countries other rules might apply (or not). I know from The Netherlands that law enforcement is often attacking doctor - patient (and client - lawyer) confidentiality.

Turtle:

And my experience has been that many smartphone owners still don‚Äôt (care to) have a good grasp on why they need it, which is concerning.

Then some people who have committed abortions should get some long prison time due to leaked sms messagess, and a lot of press to cover it. If you then still don‚Äôt care, well, then you can be the next example of sms insecurity.

anon53652:

If you then still don‚Äôt care, well, then you can be the next example of sms insecurity.

This speaks to the cognitive dissonance so many people have with tech, at least in my immediate surroundings. They can recognize that something is wrong and even express understanding that ‚Äúregular texting‚Äù isn‚Äôt private/secure, but my take is that since improving their situation would involve them actively doing something different, most won‚Äôt do much beyond complaining.

posts.name: Steven
posts.cooked: Depends how you define privacy. Lots of things are not private in the way that the security community discusses it. Do you need encryption to be private? Because hospitals use very little encrypted communication.
